data: With your newfound knowledge in matrices, let's learn about
the Dense layer. The dense layer is a single matrix
filled with weights the AI uses to learn.
tutorials/Dense Matrix.png
The size of this matrix is contolled by two factors: The
size of the data, and you. If you had 32 samples of data
that all contained 20 integers, then the number of columns
in the dense matrix would be 20 to match the size of the input.
The number of samples doesn't matter as the AI will compute
all of their losses simultaneously through the various matrices.
The rows in a dense matrix are controlled by you! Let's take a look.
Go to the 'Core' category on the left in the selection panel and drag
a Dense layer onto the Creation Canvas.
Now when you click on any layer in the Creation Canvas its settings
will be brought up here in the dialogue panel. A button will appear
so that you can easily get back to the tutorial. You will see that
a Dense layer has only a few settings: Variable Name, Units, and Activation.
Variable Name is purely cosmetic and need not change unless you want
to change the variable name this layer is assigned in the python file
that will be generated later.
The 'Units' setting is what controls the number of rows in the Dense matrix.
You may enter any number that you wish. Higher numbers allow the AI to learn
more about the data it is processing, however, this can lead to overfitting,
which is a problem every AI faces that we will discuss how to combat later on.
Typically, a few Dense layers are placed right after each other with each layer
down the line having fewer and fewer nodes (rows). This allows the AI
to pick out the truly important features of the data and even combine
different features it recognizes into a larger feature. For example, say
that two weights on the first Dense layer independently can recognize a
semi-circle and a line, which on their own doesn't mean much, but a
higher order Dense layer can take those two features and recognize that
together they form the letter 'b'!
The activation setting is something the AI needs with every layer to prepare
it for the next layer. For now we will leave it on Linear and come back to it later.
